reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

reading.reading: おたんじょうびおめでとう

reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 誕生日, so if you know that you know this!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings are all the kun'yomi readings of everything. The word 人, the word 差す, and the word 指. Take your time with this one, it's kind of weird.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings are 人 and 違い put together.

This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In order <vocabulary>to entrust something</vocabulary> to someone, you need to <reading>make a</reading> (まか) list. It's no good delegating tasks if the person has no idea what to do, so be sure to make a list, okay?

The reading for this is an exception. The reading for 何 is just the first な from なに. You can remember the second part this way:

No one knows quite <vocabulary>how</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>why</vocabulary> that big <reading>ze</reading>ppelin (ぜ) crashed in the 1930s. People are still asking today and no one has any answers. We have to keep asking until we get some.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that there's a い hiding in there!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just don't forget that extra い!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned this reading of 刺 already with 名刺, but here's a mnemonic in case it's not coming to you:

<vocabulary>Stimulation</vocabulary> for your <reading>shee</reading>p (し) is the best way to make its wool grow faster. All the woolliest sheep are stimulated daily with massages and exercise, if you think about. Sheep need stimulation!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Think about encouraging a <reading>hag</reading> (はげ). She needs encouragement because she's a hag, and nobody likes her much because of that.

I'm going to do some <vocabulary>fortune telling</vocabulary> on you... hmmm... I see... ohhhh... Looks like you'll be living on <reading>Uranu</reading>s (うらな) in your near future, that will be $50. What a dumb fortune telling for $50, you definitely won't be living there, unless he meant your butt, then maybe.

What is it you want <vocabulary>to occupy</vocabulary> most in the whole, entire world? Your own flock of <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Also, a fortune teller (this kanji also means fortune, remember) told you that if you occupy her sheep, you'll have good luck! Gotta do as she says!
You see a beautiful woman in front of you. She shows you a <vocabulary>mark</vocabulary> on a piece of paper. It's a mark that tells you she's Russian (しるし)!
This is a jukugo word, but it uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi, so watch out for that!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is 違い plus 大 of 大きい (おお) put together. You can remember this because when you see the difference (the BIG difference), you say "oohhhhh" (お), because you were surprised you didn't see it before.
The reading is the same as 届く and you can use that to deliver the memory to your brain.
The reading is 差す and 上げる put together, both hopefully words you know okay by now.

I am going <vocabulary>to obey</vocabulary> you. I think your order is a bit of <reading>shit が</reading> (したが), I'll do it and obey you. 

(Little side note, did you know が in the middle of a sentence can mean "but" in Japanese? Think of it as that meaning here.)

It is <vocabulary>I</vocabulary>! Due to my ego, I love the Wii and no other gaming device. I love playing all the Wii-<reading>ware</reading> (われ) that's available, and everything else sucks.
What is your responsibility? To raise this girl named <reading>Nina</reading> (にな).

Someone is trying <vocabulary>to shake something</vocabulary>. And unfortunately, that something is you. The most unfortunate thing here is that you're totally <reading>full</reading> (ふる), and you throw up because of the shaking (and you're full, gross!).

When thinking about the <vocabulary>circumstance</vocabulary> of your current situation and the <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary> you're there (which is studying kanji and vocab). Whose fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's <reading>yue</reading> fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you flourish at? You're an amazing <reading>soccer</reading> (さか) player who flourishes and prospers no matter where you go to play this wonderful (but not as good as baseball) sport.

The readings for everything here are the readings you learned with the individual kanji, though not all are on'yomi. This word is usually rendaku'd too, but sometimes you'll see the non-rendaku version in romaji when it comes to English language legal stuff, so keep that in mind.
The readings are all readings that you learned with the kanji, so as long as you remember them, you’re good to go!

The reading is 気 plus 違い.
The reading for 氷 is the one you didn't learn. Think of the glacier coming slowly to your door. It rings your doorbell and says <reading>heyo</reading> (ひょう). Note that the か becomes が here.
The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji. Also, your <vocabulary>sweat</vocabulary> smells like <reading>ass</reading> (あせ).
The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the same like the word 川 which has the same meaning. Associate the two to remember!

The reading for 河 makes sense. The reading for 童 however is weird. Since the meaning is "kappa" though you can use that to remember the reading as well. If you don't know what a kappa is do some research on the internets and figure out about them. It's interesting, and it will help you to remember this word.
The reading makes no sense, really. Neither kanji readings work. But, if you remember that a river pig is a fugu, you can know the reading is <reading>ふぐ</reading>as well! YOU ARE A BLOWFISH, JESSE!

The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. 

If you need a refresher, remember that the <reading>Sue Zoo</reading> (すず) was made for the penguin Sue <vocabulary>to cool off</vocabulary> in, even when it's hot outside.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
What is <vocabulary>fierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>violent</vocabulary>? That old <reading>hag</reading> (はげ). Imagine her coming at you attacking you violently!

The reading is different from the one you learned (this is kun'yomi). There's an easy way to remember it, though. 一人 and 独り share the same readings and mean almost the same thing. Just try to remember that this ひとり is used to emphasize solitude.

You have <vocabulary>to narrow</vocabulary> the width of something. The only way you can do that is to <reading>sever</reading> (せば) off each end. Maybe you're trying to get a sofa up a tight stairway. The only way to do that is by severing off each arm to narrow it.

A <vocabulary>beast</vocabulary>... what do you think of when you think of a beast? How about a thing (物, もの) full of fur (毛, け), aka a けもの (fur thing)? A beast is a fur thing, and in Japanese that's けもの. Punnnns.

The reading is the same as  過ぎる. If you know it, it's OK <vocabulary>to pass time</vocabulary> relaxing for a bit! If you don’t know it, maybe it's good <vocabulary>to spend time</vocabulary> reviewing…

If you find yourself in <vocabulary>violation</vocabulary> of the law just pull out your pet <reading>ea</reading>gle (い). Eagles are so majestic, they'll forget all about your transgression and let you go. If you're going to go be anti-something make sure you bring that eagle. People seem to care more about animals than other people like that.

You get a lot of junk <vocabulary>mail</vocabulary>, so you throw it in the waste <reading>bin</reading> (びん). The waste bin is where that mail goes.

If you do <vocabulary>acupuncture</vocabulary> and stick a bunch of needles in your back it's going to look really <reading>hairy</reading> (はり). Needles look just like metal hairs when they're coming out of someone. Just picture hairy little needles all over your body and you'll never forget this reading!
Lots of <vocabulary>lead</vocabulary>, all in bullet form. That's what it was like in <reading>nam, 'arry" (なまり).</reading>
